contextual_info.usage_reason: Lina is a queer college freshman in a conservative town. She uses the music app to feel connected to other LGBTQ+ users by seeing what they're listening to, hoping for cultural connection and affirmation.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations: She believes enabling the feature only shows what others share publicly, not realizing it can expose her own activity in unintended ways.
contextual_info.information_to_control: Lina cares deeply about controlling who sees her music activity, which often includes queer artists or songs associated with LGBTQ+ identity that she has not disclosed to family or certain classmates.

costs: Labor-intensive identity management, emotional stress, accidental exposure to unintended audiences

privacy_invasive user journey.background: Late at night in her dorm, Lina wants to feel closer to her online queer community. She heard about the Friend Activity feature and decides to activate it to see what music her friends are listening to, hoping to find comfort through shared interests and connections.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: By enabling the 'Share my listening activity' toggle to view others' activity, Lina unintentionally shares her own music activity with a classmate she recently added—who is not part of her LGBTQ+ community. The classmate takes a screenshot of her listening to a queer-coded podcast and shares it in a group chat. This results in Lina being outed to some peers, violating her privacy. The data subject is Lina; the data sender is the app system sharing Lina's activity; the data recipient is her classmate and their social group.

scenes.scene_description: Lina hears her online friend mention the Friend Activity feature and wants to feel more connected to others in the LGBTQ+ music space. She assumes she must activate something in her settings. Expecting it to only allow her to see others' music, she decides to toggle it on. 'Maybe I'll find people who like the same songs I do,' she says.

scene_user_flow.start: Lina opens the desktop app late at night in her dorm room.
scene_user_flow.interface: Home page showing current music playback and navigation bar.

scene_user_flow.action: Click on her profile picture at the top-right.
scene_user_flow.interface: Drop-down menu with Settings option appears.
Settings page with multiple category options.
Finds toggle for 'See what your friends are playing' (default OFF).

scene_user_flow.system_action: System checks for mutual friends with sharing enabled.
scene_user_flow.interface: Sidebar appears saying no visible activity and prompts her to enable 'Share my listening activity'.
Settings page reloads.
Social toggles are visible.

scene_user_flow.system_action: Lina's listening activity now starts broadcasting to all mutual followers with visibility enabled.
scene_user_flow.interface: Same sidebar appears, still no friend activity shown.
scene_user_flow.true_reasoning: She believes she has enabled the feature correctly and expects to see her friends' activity soon.
scene_user_flow.next_step: Lina returns to the homepage, waiting for activity to appear in the sidebar.

scenes.scene_description: The next morning, Lina plays a queer-themed podcast while studying. She assumes her activity is still private unless someone is actively following her.

scene_user_flow.start: Lina is on her laptop studying and plays a podcast through the app.
scene_user_flow.interface: Now playing bar shows podcast; sidebar still shows no friend activity.

scene_user_flow.action: Listens to 'Queer Earbuds', a niche podcast discussing queer identity in music.
scene_user_flow.interface: Playback continues, unaware it's now publicly visible to her network.
scene_user_flow.system_action: Activity is shared with anyone following her, including a classmate she recently added.

scene_user_flow.interface: Lina continues browsing while listening.
scene_user_flow.false_reasoning: She doesn't realize this activity is being broadcast.
scene_user_flow.next_step: Continues regular app use throughout the day.

scenes.scene_description: Later that day, Lina's classmate, who follows her out of curiosity, sees her activity and screenshots it.

scene_user_flow.start: Classmate checks Friend Activity sidebar out of boredom.
scene_user_flow.interface: Sees Lina listening to 'Queer Earbuds'.

scene_user_flow.action: Takes a screenshot and shares it in a class group chat with a snarky message.
scene_user_flow.interface: Lina's activity is now circulating beyond intended recipients.
scene_user_flow.system_action: Unintended audience now aware of Lina's private listening behavior.

scene_user_flow.interface: Screenshot exists in group chat with peers discussing it.
scene_user_flow.false_reasoning: Lina never intended to disclose her identity to that group.
scene_user_flow.next_step: She panics and rushes to turn off the sharing settings.

scenes.scene_description: Feeling violated and anxious, Lina tries to regain control over her privacy by turning the feature off.

scene_user_flow.start: Lina revisits app settings in a panic.
scene_user_flow.interface: Navigates back to Settings > Social.

scene_user_flow.action: Turns OFF 'Share my listening activity' toggle.
scene_user_flow.interface: Toggle is now OFF; sidebar still visible but no longer broadcasting her activity.
scene_user_flow.system_action: Activity feed stops sharing her listening behavior.

scene_user_flow.interface: Lina breathes a sigh of relief but feels shaken.
scene_user_flow.true_reasoning: She has disabled the feature, but the damage from the screenshot cannot be undone.
scene_user_flow.next_step: She considers deleting her account or using a secondary identity moving forward.

contextual_info.usage_reason: Carlos is a single father in a rural area. He uses the music app to connect with his teenage daughter, who lives with her mother in another state. He thinks viewing her music activity will help him understand her better and feel more connected.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations: Carlos thinks enabling the Friend Activity feature is like a private window into what people are listening to, not realizing others can see his activity too.
contextual_info.information_to_control: He wants to keep his own listening activity private, especially old romantic songs he listens to while coping with loneliness.

costs: Emotional embarrassment, misunderstanding from others, surveillance from family

privacy_invasive user journey.background: Carlos, sitting alone after work, wants to connect with his daughter through music. He tries to enable Friend Activity to see what she's into lately. He doesn't know this will share his own listening data too.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: Carlos's daughter sees his listening history full of sad romantic music, assumes he's emotionally unstable, and shares concern with her mother. This leads to a custody review discussion. The data subject is Carlos; the data sender is the app; the data recipients are his daughter and ex-wife.

contextual_info.usage_reason: Noor is a digital activist in a restrictive country. She uses the app for stress relief and curates playlists that include protest music. She enables Friend Activity to monitor the musical climate among her network.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations: She believes using private sessions will fully hide her listening activity. However, she forgets to turn it on once, thinking it's enabled by default.
contextual_info.information_to_control: She wants to keep any political or protest-related listening hidden due to fear of state surveillance or employer retaliation.

costs: Social liability, increased surveillance, possible legal risk

privacy_invasive user journey.background: Noor is prepping for an online activist campaign and listens to a curated playlist of protest songs for inspiration. She had used 'private session' in the past but forgets to activate it this time after a software update reset the setting.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: A colleague sees her listening to politically charged content and reports it to their manager. Noor is called in for questioning by HR and warned to keep her personal beliefs off company platforms. The data subject is Noor; data sender is the app; data recipient is a coworker and HR.
